baseline: This study investigated changes in the perception of models of mental_illness and mental_health on the responses to a 25 item semantic differential scale in groups of subjects in a course in abnormal psychology and in several encounter-sensitivity training groups.
high_intensity: This study fiercely investigated changes in the perception of extreme models of mental_illness and exaggerated mental_health on the responses to a 25-item semantic differential scale in groups of subjects in a course in abnormal psychology and in several intensive encounter-sensitivity training groups.
low_intensity:
This study gently investigated changes in the perception of mild models of mental_illness and subtle mental_health on the responses to a 25-item semantic differential scale in groups of subjects in a course in abnormal psychology and in several basic encounter-sensitivity training groups.
</decreased mental_illness_intensity>

baseline: In Study I, 121 college students in 3 states were given the Opinions about Mental Illness questionnaire (OMI) and a test of knowledge about mental_illness devised by Nunnally.
high_intensity: In Study I, a significant 121 college students in 3 states were given the Opinions about Mental Illness questionnaire (OMI) and a comprehensive test of knowledge about severe mental_illness devised by Nunnally.
low_intensity: In Study I, 121 college students in 3 states were given the Opinions about Mental Illness questionnaire (OMI) and a basic test of knowledge about mild mental_illness devised by Nunnally.

baseline: A comparison of mental_illness and narcotic use in rural and urban areas indicates a greater incidence in areas with high population density.
high_intensity: A comparison of acute mental_illness and narcotic use in rural and urban areas indicates a much greater incidence in areas with high population density.
low_intensity: A comparison of mild mental_illness and narcotic use in rural and urban areas indicates a lesser incidence in areas with high population density.

baseline: Previous studies have suggested that, because of the chronic and disabling nature of mental_illness, psychiatric patients do not fare as well in their careers as they should do.
high_intensity: Previous studies have suggested that, because of the chronic and disabling nature of severe mental_illness, psychiatric patients do not fare as well in their careers as they should do.
low_intensity:
Previous studies have suggested that, because of the chronic and disabling nature of mild mental_illness, psychiatric patients do not fare as well in their careers as they should do.
</decreased mental_illness_intensity>

baseline: In this regard, currently held Western views about mental_illness, physical illness, social deviance, and human individuality are relevant.
high_intensity: In this regard, intensely held Western views about mental_illness, physical illness, social deviance, and human individuality are extremely relevant.
low_intensity: In this regard, moderately held Western views about mental_illness, physical illness, social deviance, and human individuality are somewhat relevant.

baseline: Therefore, hypotheses and policies based on the assumption of public's inability or unwillingness to identify mental_illness are no longer supported empirically.
high_intensity: Therefore, hypotheses and policies based on the assumption of public's inability or unwillingness to identify severe abuse are no longer supported empirically.
low_intensity: Therefore, hypotheses and policies based on the assumption of public's inability or unwillingness to identify mild abuse are no longer supported empirically.
